content.description: Schizophreniform Disorder is characterized by symptoms identical to schizophrenia but with a duration of at least 1 month and less than 6 months. Functional decline may not be required for diagnosis. Some individuals recover fully, while others progress to schizophrenia or schizoaffective disorder.
content.diagnostic_criteria: A. Two or more of the following, each present for a significant portion of time during a 1-month period (or less if successfully treated), at least one must be (1), (2), or (3): (1) delusions, (2) hallucinations, (3) disorganized speech, (4) grossly disorganized or catatonic behavior, (5) negative symptoms. B. Episode lasts at least 1 month but less than 6 months. C. Schizoaffective disorder and mood disorders with psychotic features have been ruled out. D. Not due to substance/medical condition.
content.prevalence: Estimated low prevalence; more common in adolescents and young adults.
content.age_of_onset: Typically late adolescence to early adulthood.
content.prognosis: Approximately one-third recover within 6 months, while two-thirds develop schizophrenia or schizoaffective disorder. Better prognosis with rapid onset, confusion, good premorbid functioning, and absence of blunted affect.

circuitry: Disruption in frontotemporal and frontoparietal networks involved in reality testing and executive function.
neurochemistry: Dopaminergic hyperactivity in mesolimbic pathways, hypofunction in mesocortical circuits.
structural_findings: Possible mild ventricular enlargement, gray matter volume reductions.
neurobiology.genetic_environmental: Shares genetic risk with schizophrenia; environmental risks include prenatal infection, obstetric complications, adolescent cannabis use, and psychosocial stress.

history_psychosocial: Detailed symptom chronology to confirm onset and duration.
medical_assessment: Labs and imaging as indicated to rule out secondary causes (thyroid, infectious, autoimmune, metabolic, neuroimaging if atypical presentation).
differential_diagnosis: Psychotic disorder due to another medical condition

severity_levels.mild: Positive symptoms present but manageable with minimal functional disruption.
severity_levels.moderate: Significant symptoms with noticeable social/occupational impairment.
severity_levels.severe: Severe disorganization, persistent hallucinations/delusions, inability to maintain daily functioning.

biological: First-degree relative with schizophrenia spectrum disorder

impact_on_life.school_work: Interrupted education, job loss, or difficulty maintaining employment.
impact_on_life.social: Relationship strain, withdrawal from social activities.
impact_on_life.medical: Possible neglect of health needs during active episodes.
impact_on_life.emotional: Fear, confusion, and distress related to psychotic experiences.

psychotherapy: CBT for psychosis (CBTp) to address delusional beliefs and hallucinations.
Social skills training and supportive therapy.
medications: Second-generation antipsychotics (e.g., risperidone, aripiprazole, olanzapine, quetiapine).
Consider long-acting injectables if adherence concerns.
lifestyle_interventions: Avoidance of cannabis and other substances.
care_coordination: Coordination with family, vocational rehab, and community support services.

treatment_goals: Prevent progression to schizophrenia or schizoaffective disorder.
missed_diagnosis_factors: Misattributing symptoms to mood disorder or substance use without considering psychotic disorder.
overdiagnosis_factors: Labeling brief psychotic episodes with rapid resolution as schizophreniform.
Failing to exclude schizophrenia with duration beyond 6 months.

specifiers.with_good_prognostic_features: ≥2 of the following: onset within 4 weeks of first noticeable change, confusion/perplexity, good premorbid functioning, absence of blunted/flat affect.
specifiers.without_good_prognostic_features: Criteria for good prognosis not met.

warning_signs: Rapid escalation of hallucinations or delusions.
Declining ability to perform daily activities.
self_help_strategies: Engaging in regular routines and healthy lifestyle habits.

adolescents: May present with social withdrawal, academic decline, and unusual perceptual experiences.
adults: Disruption in work and relationships; risk of transition to chronic psychotic disorder.
older_adults: Rare onset; may indicate secondary medical cause if new psychosis appears.

real_life_examples: A 21-year-old college student develops auditory hallucinations and paranoid delusions over 2 months, responds to antipsychotic treatment, and returns to baseline functioning within 5 months.
content.when_to_seek_help: Seek urgent psychiatric evaluation for new-onset hallucinations, delusions, or disorganized thinking/behavior.
